qas.question: What new subject surface at the end of the 18th century?
Who realized that languages like Sanskrit, Persian, and Greek share the same foundation?
What did Sir William Jones do to document his work?

answers.text: catalog all languages of the world

qas.question: What did Noam Chomsky add to the study of linguistics?
What method did Chomsky use to develop generative linguistics?

context: <a0_0>Historical linguistics<a0_0/> emerged as an independent field of study at the end of the 18th century. <a1_0>Sir William Jones<a1_0/> proposed that Sanskrit, Persian, Greek, Latin, Gothic, and Celtic languages all shared a common base. After Jones, an effort to <a2_0>catalog all languages of the world<a2_0/> was made throughout the 19th century and into the 20th century. Publication of Ferdinand de Saussure's Cours de linguistique générale created the development of descriptive linguistics. Descriptive linguistics, and the related structuralism movement caused linguistics to focus on how language changes over time, instead of just describing the differences between languages. Noam Chomsky further diversified linguistics with <a3_0>the development of generative linguistics<a3_0/> in the 1950s. His effort is based upon <a4_0>a mathematical model of language<a4_0/> that allows for the description and prediction of valid syntax. Additional specialties such as sociolinguistics, cognitive linguistics, and computational linguistics have emerged from collaboration between linguistics and other disciplines.
